title: Bulgaria goalkeeper Iliev says England overreacted to racial abuse
text:
Plamen Iliev has criticised England’s players after they were racially abused (Picture: Getty Images)

Bulgaria goalkeeper Plamen Iliev has shockingly claimed that England’s players overreacted to the racial abuse they suffered on Monday night and that the home fans in Sofia ‘behaved well.’

England’s 6-0 win over Bulgaria was stopped twice in the first half as some of the home fans made monkey chants directed at Tyrone Mings and Raheem Sterling.

Despite this, Iliev has defended his country’s supporters and suggested that England should not have complained to the referee, which led to the game being paused.

‘If I am honest, I believe they [the fans] behaved well today,’ Iliev said. ‘There wasn’t any abuse [as far as I could hear] and I think they [the England players] overreacted a bit.

‘The public was on a good level – I didn’t hear any bad language used towards their or our players.’

The Bulgaria manager, Krasimir Balakov, was also dismissive of the abysmal scenes in Sofia, claiming that he did not hear any chanting and that England fans were in the wrong.

‘I personally did not hear the chanting,’ said Balakov. ‘I saw the referee stopped the game but I also have to say the behaviour was also not only on behalf of the Bulgarian fans but also the English fans, who were whistling and shouting during the Bulgarian national anthem.

‘During the second half they used words against our fans which I find unacceptable.’
